[satisfied] Yeah, um, funny how being a decent human being, well, actually pays off sometimes, [smug], isn't it? [chuckles darkly]

[breaking] This is, um, insane—I've been sending her money every month, well, paying for this house and, [frantic], everything she needs. [voice cracks]
[harsh] Money again—that's all you, um, ever think matters but she needed someone to, well, hold her hand during chemo, not just, uh, wire transfers from your, [bitter], offshore accounts.
[vulnerable] I didn't know she was, um, that sick because she never told me and, well, I thought the money meant I was, [lost], taking care of her.
She didn't tell you because, well, you made it clear that, [cold], your precious derivatives and margins were more, [cutting], important than Sunday dinners or holiday visits, um.
[defeated] Can I at least see her, [pleading], before you throw me out of what used to be, [broken], my childhood home?
[considering] She's sleeping now but you can, [reluctant], wait in the kitchen where you used to, [nostalgic], make fun of me for eating alone.
I guess we both ended up, well, exactly where we, [hollow], deserved to be, didn't we—me with, um, all the money and none of the, [empty], love. [sighs heavily]
